REVISED NAEB POLICY PAPER FOR DISCUSSION
I. BASIC. ASSUMPTIONS
A. Radio will continue to be an important medium of
communication.
B. Television as a tool of education will continue
to grow and develop.
C. There is an increasing appetite and clientele
for educational services of all kinds in
America today. Radio and television hold great
promise as devices for helping to satisfy this
demand.
D. Schools and colleges will need to develop an increas¬
ing awareness of the necessity of utilizing all media
of communications if there responsibilities are to
be fulfilled. The costs for adequate radio and television
facilities and use will therefore/jy^aai&stM of necessity
come to be recognized as a fundamental and vital part
of regular and legitimate instructional costs.
E. (Therefore A and B above are true and) The NAEB has
a long-range future. Being membership based, it has
the natural organizational structure needed to pro¬
vide regular services to its member stations with
hope of recovery of costs in whole or in part. At
least regular services can be supported by the membership,
although temporary, special services, of the sort now
needed for television, will for sometime require outside
support. The NAEB will continue to operate a radio
network. A similar service for television will be a
necessity.
F. There will continue to be a need for assistance in
the development of educational television stations
and production centers, as well as help in launching
comparable radio facilities.
